contentrichtext.text: {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} An '''Anisothermal plasma''' is a [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] which thermal state can be approximated by more than one temperature for the different [[degrees of freedom (physics and chemistry)|degrees of freedom]] of the plasma. The degrees of freedom refer to translation ([[kinetic energy]]), rotation, vibration of each particle type. Examples of anisothermal plasmas can be found among low-pressure plasmas that are excited by high frequency [[electric field]]s, see [[frequency classification of plasmas]]. They generally exhibit hot [[electron]]s that are powered by the alternating electric field, and a neutral and [[ion]] component, which is significantly colder due the low efficiency of the energy transfer between light electrons and heavy neutrals and ions. The term [[nonthermal plasma]] includes anisothermal plasmas and means that the different degrees of freedom of the plasma are ''not'' in [[thermal equilibrium]]. ==See also== *[[List of plasma (physics) articles]] {{Empty section|date=July 2010}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== [[Category:Plasma physics]] {{physics-stub}}
